description: Cognitive Function encompasses the mental processes that allow us to carry out any task that requires processing and understanding information.

children.description: Memory involves the processes related to the encoding, storage, and retrieval of information.
Short-Term Memory involves the capacity to hold a small amount of information in an active, readily available state for a short period of time.
Verbal Short-Term Memory is the ability to hold verbal information, such as words and numbers, in mind for short periods.
Phonological Short-Term Memory refers to the retention of phonetic or auditory-verbal information over brief intervals.
Lexical Short-Term Memory involves retaining words or lexical information for short durations.
Visual Short-Term Memory is the capacity to hold visual information, like images and shapes, in mind for short durations.
Object Short-Term Memory involves the temporary retention of objects or detailed visual features.
Spatial Short-Term Memory refers to the temporary remembrance of spatial information like locations or patterns.
Long-Term Memory involves the storage of information over extended periods, ranging from minutes to a lifetime.
Episodic Memory encompasses the ability to recall personal experiences and specific events from one's past.
Autobiographical Memory relates to the capacity to recall personal life events and experiences.
Flashbulb Memory involves vividly detailed and enduring memory of significant events.
Semantic Memory refers to the memory of facts, concepts, and general knowledge about the world.
Conceptual Knowledge entails understanding and memory of categories, synonyms, or features of different entities.
Lexical Knowledge pertains to the retention of word meanings and language-related information.
Procedural Memory involves the memory of motor skills and actions.
Motor Sequence Learning is the memory and acquisition of sequences of movements.
Skill Acquisition involves learning and refining new motor skills through practice.
Working Memory refers to the temporary storage and manipulation of information necessary for complex cognitive tasks.
Phonological Loop refers to the component of working memory involved in holding and processing verbal and auditory information.
Articulatory Rehearsal Component involves subvocal repetition to keep verbal information active.
Phonological Store is responsible for the retention of speech-based information over short durations.
Visuospatial Sketchpad is the part of working memory that retains visual and spatial information.
Visual Cache holds onto color and form data temporarily.
Inner Scribe helps manipulate spatial and movement data within short-term visual memory.
Executive Functioning refers to a set of cognitive processes that are necessary for the cognitive control of behavior, including tasks such as problem-solving, planning, and attention management.
Inhibitory Control involves the ability to suppress automatic, dominant, or prepotent responses while selecting appropriate behavior that is consistent with completing a task or goal.
Response Inhibition is the ability to suppress actions that are inappropriate or no longer required.
Prepotent Inhibition involves controlling automatic tendencies and impulses.
Semantic Inhibition is the ability to suppress irrelevant meanings or associations during cognitive tasks.
Interference Control involves the ability to resist distractions and maintain focus.
Cognitive Interference refers to perturbations disrupting focus, arising from competing thoughts or memories.
Perceptual Interference involves the disruption in processing due to irrelevant sensory input.
Cognitive Flexibility is the mental ability to switch between thinking about different concepts, and to think about multiple concepts simultaneously.
Task Switching refers to shifting attention between different tasks or mental processes.
Simple Task Shifting involves alternating attention between less complex tasks or stimuli.
Set Shifting involves changing one's approach or strategy in response to changing demands or rules.
Perseverance Reduction pertains to minimizing repetitive or unproductive thought patterns in favor of adaptable thinking.
Processing Speed is the pace at which individuals can perceive, understand, and respond to information.
Perceptual Speed refers to the ability to quickly and accurately compare or process visual stimuli.
Visual Perceptual Speed is the rate of processing visual information quickly and accurately.
Cognitive Speed involves the quick and efficient processing of information in the brain.
Mental Calculation Speed refers to the rapid processing and calculation of problems without external aids.
Attention encompasses the mental processes involved in focusing on specific stimuli while ignoring others.
Selective Attention is the capacity to focus on relevant stimuli while ignoring irrelevant distractions.
Visual Selective Attention concerns focusing on relevant visual stimuli and ignoring distractions.
Visual Background Discrimination involves distinguishing relevant figures from a complex visual field.
Auditory Selective Attention involves focusing on specific sounds or voices while ignoring other auditory inputs.
Speech Filtering concerns focusing on specific speech or conversations while disregarding auditory noise.
The ability to identify and understand one's own emotions and the emotions of others.
Identifying emotions through the recognition of facial expressions.
The ability to perceive and interpret brief, involuntary facial expressions that reveal genuine emotions.
Understanding how different cultures express emotions differently through facial expressions.
Understanding emotions conveyed through vocal tone or intonation.
The ability to identify rhythmic and intonational aspects of vocal tone that convey emotional context.
Recognizing emotional characteristics of voice tone, such as warmth or harshness.
The capacity to comprehend emotional language and situations, integrating emotional information into one's life and actions.
The ability to understand and share the feelings of another.
Experiencing the emotions that another person is feeling.
Understanding another person's perspective and emotions without necessarily feeling them.
Understanding emotions in relation to specific situations and contexts.
Evaluating and interpreting emotional dynamics within specific situations.
Understanding how time and sequence influence emotional reactions and contexts.
The regulation and control of emotions, including the modulation of emotional responses and the ability to handle stress.
Techniques and strategies to manage and regulate stress effectively.
Practices like meditation, deep breathing, and progressive muscle relaxation to reduce stress.
The ability to change one's interpretation of a situation to alter its emotional impact.
The ability to resist or delay an emotional or behavioral impulse.
The capacity to resist the temptation for an immediate reward in preference for a later reward.
The ability to suppress inappropriate or unwanted responses.
The ability to express emotions in a healthy, socially acceptable manner.
Expressing emotions through spoken language.
The clarity and effectiveness with which emotions are expressed through words.
The range of emotion-related words a person uses to express themselves.
Conveying emotions through body language, gestures, and facial expressions.
Using physical gestures to express emotions.
Emotion conveyed through body posture.
The degree to which one is cognizant of emotions and their effects.
Being aware of one's own emotions as they arise.
The practice of reflecting on one's own emotional experiences and patterns.
Understanding how physical sensations are related to emotional states.
Recognizing and understanding the emotions of others.
The ability to detect emotional states in others through social signals and cues.
The ability to see and feel things from another's emotional viewpoint.

description: This dimension involves the ways individuals interact with others in social contexts, encompassing the ability to engage, communicate, and establish relationships in various environments.

children.description: The ability to accurately interpret and understand others' emotional states, intentions, and social cues.
The ability to identify and recognize emotions from facial expressions.
The skill to notice and interpret brief, involuntary facial expressions that reveal genuine emotions.
Identifying minimal facial muscle activations that indicate specific emotional states.
The capacity to understand that others have beliefs, desires, and perspectives that are different from one's own.
The ability to recognize that another person can hold a false belief about a situation.
The capability to understand how misleading information leads others to form incorrect beliefs.
The capacity to read and understand non-verbal cues from body language during interactions.
The ability to understand attitudes and emotions through analysis of body postures.
Combining posture with gestures to enhance understanding of body language.
The ability to discern emotions or intentions from the tone of voice and speech patterns.
The ability to interpret changes in voice tone to understand underlying emotions.
Analyzing speech rhythm and emphasis to gather emotional cues.
The capacity to effectively express oneself and interpret others' verbal and non-verbal communication in social contexts.
The ability to effectively convey and interpret messages using spoken language.
The ability to construct and understand stories and sequences of events in communication.
Ensuring coherence and logical flow in verbal storytelling.
The ability to use and understand body language, gestures, facial expressions, and other non-verbal cues during interactions.
The ability to recognize and interpret common gestures in communication.
Understanding how gesture meanings vary across different cultural contexts.
The ability to use language effectively and appropriately in social contexts, understanding the nuances of conversation.
The skill to modify language and communication style to suit different social contexts and audiences.
Switching linguistic register according to social situations.
The capacity to fully concentrate, understand, and respond during interactions.
The skill to mirror back what has been said to confirm understanding and show empathy.
Providing feedback that acknowledges emotional content during listening.
The skill of forming and maintaining meaningful connections and interactions with others.
The ability to establish and maintain trust in interpersonal relationships.
The skill to evaluate and establish reliability and trustworthiness in others.
Utilizing communication strategies that foster trust.
The skill to effectively resolve disagreements and conflicts in social interactions.
A method of resolving conflicts by understanding and addressing underlying interests and needs.
Creating solutions that meet the interests of all parties involved.
The practice of exchanging things with others for mutual benefit, including social gestures and communications.
The understanding and practice of exchanging beneficial acts between individuals over time.
Recognizing and accepting deferred reciprocation in social exchanges.
The capacity to create and maintain a web of social ties and relationships over time.
The ability to leverage one's network for information, support, and opportunities.
Engaging in planned interactions to develop beneficial connections.
The ability to understand and share the feelings of others, facilitating compassionate and supportive interactions.
The capacity to respond with appropriate emotion to another's mental states.
The ability to experience and resonate with the emotions of others closely.
The skill to manage one's emotional response when resonating with others.
The capability to understand another's perspective or mental state.
Techniques to effectively put oneself in another's mental and emotional shoes.
Exploring a wide range of perspectives to enhance empathy.
The mental processes involved in understanding, processing, and responding to social information.
How individuals explain the causes of behavior and events, particularly in social contexts.
The tendency to attribute personal failures to oneself and its social implications.
Considering external factors as potential causes of events.
The ability to navigate and resolve problems that occur in social interactions.
The skill to work together with others to solve shared social problems.
Developing solutions collaboratively that creatively address social problems.
The skill to understand a situation from another person's point of view.
The ability to accurately infer the specific content of other people's thoughts and feelings.
Focusing on small details to improve accuracy in understanding thoughts and feelings.
The ability to understand and adapt to cultural differences in social contexts.
The skill to effectively function and communicate within diverse cultural contexts.
Building skills to communicate and engage across cultures.

description: The capacity to convey thoughts, feelings, and information through a shared system of symbols, signs, and behaviors.

children.description: The ability to understand information. It involves understanding the words, sentences, and meaning of what others say or what is read.
Understanding spoken language through listening.
The ability to comprehend and execute spoken instructions or commands.
Understanding and following instructions that require multiple actions or steps.
Arranging tasks or steps in the correct order as given in instructions.
Understanding time-related language such as sequences and temporal words (e.g., first, next, then).
The ability to focus on and understand spoken information and stories.
Understanding the elements and structure of a story or spoken narrative.
Identifying and understanding the main events and structure of a narrative.
Comprehending characters' motivations, feelings, and development in narratives.
Understanding written language and texts.
The ability to read between the lines and understand the implied meanings in texts.
Using context within text to derive meaning.
Applying general rules to reach specific conclusions.
Drawing broad conclusions from specific information or patterns in text.
Grasping the explicit meanings of text as written.
Recognizing factual information and details in texts.
The ability to express thoughts, feelings, and ideas through speech, writing, gestures, or other forms.
The use of spoken words to convey messages.
The clarity and pronunciation of speech sounds.
Producing speech sounds correctly within words.
The clarity with which speech can be understood by others.
Breaking down words into individual sounds for accurate articulation.
The use of writing to communicate thoughts and ideas.
The ability to arrange letters in the correct order to form words correctly.
Identifying common spelling patterns in words.
Recalling and visualizing the structure and spelling of words.
Applying spelling rules accurately in written communication.
Using gestures or facial expressions to communicate without words.
The use of hand and body movements to express ideas or feelings.
Using gestures that have specific, understood meanings or signals.
Understanding and applying gestures based on cultural contexts and meanings.
The use of language in social contexts, understanding both verbal and non-verbal cues, and adhering to conversational rules.
The ability to maintain and understand a conversation, including taking turns and staying on topic.
Effectively exchanging dialogue in a conversation.
Knowing when and how to interrupt or interject appropriately in conversation.
Understanding the appropriate timing for comments and interruptions in dialogue.
The ability to interpret gestures, facial expressions, and other non-verbal signals in communication.
Identifying and understanding emotions through facial expressions and body language.
Recognizing less obvious emotional signals in facial expressions or body language.
Detecting and interpreting brief, involuntary facial expressions that reveal emotions.
The use of the phonological system to process spoken and written language, including the ability to hear and manipulate sounds in words.
Recognizing and manipulating individual sounds in words.
Combining individual sounds to form words.
Blending the beginning sounds with the rest of the word.
Recognizing and producing the ending sounds in words.
The ability to remember spoken information for a short period.
Recalling words or short phrases heard.
Quickly recalling a list of words after hearing them.
The ability to remember sequences of verbal information.
The aspect of language concerned with understanding and producing meaningful words and sentences.
The process of learning and using words and their meanings.
The ability to recall and use the appropriate word when needed.
The speed at which words can be recalled from memory when needed.
The effectiveness of accessing and using semantic relationships in word recall.
Understanding how different words and concepts relate to one another.
Grouping words and concepts based on shared characteristics.
Understanding and sorting categories by levels of specificity.
Differentiating between general and specific groups within categories.
The ability to process and understand the structure of sentences and grammar rules.
Recognizing and using grammatical rules and sentence construction.
Analyzing sentence structure to understand meaning.
Breaking down sentences into clauses to understand complex grammatical structures.
Clarifying sentences with multiple possible meanings or structures.
Understanding and using the smallest units of meaning in a language, such as prefixes and suffixes.
Understanding and applying both prefixes and suffixes to change meanings.
Applying rules for adding prefixes and suffixes correctly.
Understanding word formation and structure through morphological components.

description: Behavioral Control involves the ability to regulate and manage one's actions, impulses, and emotions to achieve goals or adhere to norms.

children.description: The ability to resist urges and impulses to act inappropriately or prematurely.
The ability to suppress physical responses or actions.
The ability to suppress small, precise physical movements or responses.
The ability to suppress large body movements or broader physical responses.
The capacity to wait in order to achieve a greater reward.
The ability to wait for a specified period.
The ability to wait under certain conditions or criteria.
The capacity to manage and respond to an emotional experience in a socially acceptable and flexible manner.
Recognizing and understanding one's own emotions and those of others.
Recognizing and understanding one’s own emotions.
Recognizing and understanding the emotions of others.
The ability to effectively and appropriately express emotions.
Expressing emotions through spoken or written words.
Expressing emotions through facial expressions, body language, and tone of voice.

description: This dimension encompasses the overall physical well-being and the engagement in physical activities. It represents the ability to maintain physical health through exercise, proper nutrition, and rest, as well as the capability to engage in various physical activities.

children.description: Represents the state of physical well-being and the absence of illness or injury. It includes factors such as body composition, strength, and flexibility.
Refers to the proportion of fat and non-fat mass in the body. It is a key indicator of overall health.
The amount of muscle tissue in the body, critical for strength and metabolic health.
The proportion of a person's weight that is made up of fat. An important indicator of health risk factors.
The ability of muscles to exert force during an activity. It is a fundamental aspect of physical health.
Strength in the muscles of the upper body, important for tasks involving lifting and carrying.
Strength in the muscles of the lower body, important for locomotion and power.
The range of motion available at a joint. It plays a crucial role in overall physical well-being.
The degree of movement possible at a joint, affecting overall mobility.
The ability of muscle tissue to return to its original shape after being stretched, linked to injury prevention.
Focuses on dietary habits and nutritional intake that support physical health and activity. It encompasses the quality and quantity of food consumed, as well as its impact on physical well-being.
The measure of how well a diet meets the nutritional needs of an individual. It considers factors such as variety, balance, and richness of nutrients.
The balance of proteins, carbohydrates, and fats in the diet, crucial for maintaining energy levels and bodily functions.
The consumption of vitamins and minerals essential for health, affecting immune function and development.
The total number of calories consumed, which should align with the individual's energy expenditure.
The number of calories required to keep your body functioning at rest, influencing total caloric needs.
The number of calories used by the body in physical activity and basic metabolic functions.
Concerns the regular engagement in physical exercise to maintain or improve physical fitness. This includes cardiovascular fitness, strength training, flexibility exercises, and endurance.
The ability of the heart and lungs to supply oxygen to the body during sustained physical activity.
The maximum amount of oxygen the body can use during intense exercise, linked to endurance performance.
The speed at which the heart rate returns to normal after exercise, indicating cardiovascular fitness.
Exercises designed to improve muscle strength and endurance. It involves the use of resistance to induce muscular contraction.
A form of exercise that improves muscular strength and endurance using free weights, resistance bands, or machines.
Exercises that use the individual's body weight to provide resistance against gravity, such as push-ups and squats.
Physical activities that enhance the range of motion of muscles and joints.
Holding a stretch for an extended period to improve flexibility.
Movement-based stretching that increases flexibility and blood flow before physical activity.
The ability to sustain prolonged physical or mental effort.
The ability of a muscle to sustain repeated contractions against resistance for an extended period.
The efficiency with which the body delivers oxygen and nutrients needed for muscular activity and transports waste products from the cells.
The capacity of cells to utilize and convert oxygen through metabolic processes, impacting energy production and endurance.
The ability of muscles to withstand and continue to function during high levels of lactic acid production, crucial for enduring intense exercise.
Addresses the importance of adequate rest for physical rejuvenation and recovery. It involves understanding sleep patterns, quality of sleep, and recovery strategies.
The cycle of sleep stages an individual undergoes during a sleep period. It affects overall restfulness and recovery.
A phase of sleep involving rapid eye movement, crucial for cognitive functions and restorative processes.
The stage of sleep that is most restorative, promoting physical recovery and health.
The degree to which sleep is restful and restorative, affecting health, mood, and performance.
The total amount of time spent sleeping, impacting overall health and functioning.
The degree to which sleep is uninterrupted and consistent, important for feeling rested.
The time it takes to transition from full wakefulness to sleep, impacting the overall sleep period.
The occurrence of disruptions during sleep, affecting restfulness and recovery quality.
Techniques and methods used to enhance recovery from physical activity or stress.
Low-intensity exercise following a strenuous workout to improve circulation and reduce soreness.
Rest methods involving minimal physical activity to allow the body to recuperate fully.
The use of temperature applications such as heat or ice packs to facilitate recovery and reduce pain.
Using appropriate fluids and nutrients to replenish and repair the body post-exercise.
Involves the ability to use the body effectively during physical activities, focusing on coordination, balance, and fine as well as gross motor skills.
The coordination of small muscles, in movements—usually involving the synchronization of hands and fingers with the eyes.
The skill and ease in using the hands to perform complex tasks, important for precision tasks.
The ability of the vision system to coordinate the information received through the eyes to control, guide, and direct the hands in the accomplishment of a given task.

description: This dimension encompasses the processes involved in focusing on specific stimuli and interpreting sensory information. It involves the ability to selectively concentrate on certain elements of the environment while ignoring others and the capacity to organize and make sense of sensory input.

children.description: The ability to maintain focus on a task or stimulus over an extended period of time without becoming distracted.
The ability to maintain concentrated attention over prolonged periods of time, especially in tasks requiring continuous responsiveness to events.
The ability to distinguish signal from noise over a prolonged monitoring task, demonstrating accuracy and sensitivity.
The state of responsiveness to important or urgent events by maintaining high sensory awareness.
The mental effort directed towards a content, object, or task, allowing for increased focus over shorter periods compared to vigilance.
The ability to perform and maintain focus during complex mental tasks requiring arithmetic operations.
The ability to maintain intense focus and understanding while reading lengthy or complex material.
The ability to concentrate on a particular stimulus while ignoring irrelevant information in the environment.
The act of directing attention towards a specific stimulus while ignoring distractions.
The ability to maintain focus despite the presence of competing and potentially interfering stimuli.
The ability to amplify the attentional resources towards the task-relevant stimuli.
The process of deciding which sensory information to focus on and which to ignore.
The ability to block out irrelevant thoughts or noise in order to focus attention on a particular task.
The skill of ranking environmental stimuli based on relevance or importance to the task at hand.
The capacity to attend to multiple stimuli or tasks simultaneously.
The ability to shift attention between tasks and manage multiple responsibilities effectively.
The ability to reduce the perceptual load when switching attention between tasks or parts of a task.
The skill of organizing and handling tasks in a fluid, sequenced order.
Performing two or more activities at the same time, requiring the division of attention.
The capacity to interpret and respond to multiple sources of information simultaneously.
The strategic distribution of mental resources to different task demands concurrently.
The process of recognizing, organizing, and interpreting sensory information received from the environment through sight, sound, touch, taste, and smell.
The ability to interpret and make sense of visual information from the environment.
The ability to perceive the world in three dimensions and judge the distance of an object.
The process of perceiving depth based on the visual input from both eyes, allowing for accurate depth judgment.
The ability to perceive depth based on the relative movement of objects as one moves.
The ability to distinguish and identify different colors and their properties such as hue, brightness, and saturation.
The ability to differentiate between various colors on the spectrum.
The ability to perceive the light intensity of different colors.
The ability to identify and recognize visual patterns, shapes, and structures in the environment.
The ability to identify and distinguish between different human faces.
The ability to recognize and categorize objects in the environment based on visual input.
The ability to identify, interpret, and attach meaning to sound stimuli.
The ability to perceive and differentiate between different pitches or tones in sounds.
The ability to match musical notes based on pitch.
The ability to distinguish between sounds of different frequencies.
The ability to understand and process spoken language, distinguishing words and phonemes.
The ability to detect, differentiate, and understand distinct phonetic sounds of a language.
The ability to interpret the rhythm, stress, and intonation of speech.
The ability to perceive and interpret information through touch, including texture, temperature, and pressure.
The ability to recognize and differentiate between various surface textures through touch.
The skill in distinguishing subtle differences in texture using touch sensors.
The aptitude for detecting and recognizing complex patterns in textures.
The ability to perceive changes in temperature through skin contact.
The ability to distinguish between different temperatures and temperature changes.
The process of reduced sensitivity to persistent temperature stimuli over time.

description: The capacity to effectively manage daily living tasks and adapt to changes and challenges in one’s environment.

children.description: Basic self-care tasks such as bathing, dressing, eating, and toileting.
Tasks related to personal cleanliness such as bathing and brushing teeth.
Ability to independently bathe and maintain body cleanliness.
Ability to independently set up a shower or bath, including adjusting water temperature and gathering necessary supplies.
Skills related to maintaining skin hygiene and health post-bathing.
Ability to independently select appropriate clothing and dress oneself.
Ability to choose appropriate clothing based on weather and occasion.
Selecting clothing suitable for current weather conditions.
Choosing attire that is culturally or situationally suitable (e.g., formal events).
Ability to feed oneself, including the use of utensils appropriately.
Skills related to using forks, knives, and spoons correctly.
Advanced skills in using cutlery for different types of food.
Ability to begin and manage feeding oneself without assistance.
Ability to plan and prepare meals for oneself.
More complex activities related to independent living, including managing finances, medication management, housekeeping, and transportation.
Ability to budget, manage money, and plan finances.
Understanding and managing regular income and sources of revenue.
Basic understanding of investments and how they can impact financial health.
Skills necessary to correctly administer medications as prescribed.
Knowledge of correct dosages and timing for medication intake.
Ability to create and follow a schedule for taking medications.
Ability to maintain a clean and organized living space.
Developing and adhering to a regular cleaning schedule.
Ability to perform thorough cleaning tasks beyond regular upkeep.
Skills related to maintaining employment, such as job performance, interactions with coworkers and supervisors, and task efficiency.
Ability to complete work tasks accurately and efficiently.
Ability to organize and manage tasks logically and efficiently.
Skills in determining the order and importance of tasks to optimize efficiency.
Effective communication with coworkers and supervisors.
Skills in managing and resolving workplace conflicts effectively.
Ability to facilitate discussions and resolve disputes between parties.
The ability to utilize free time effectively, engage in hobbies, and participate in group or individual recreational activities.
Ability to pursue individual hobbies regularly.
Improving and advancing personal skills related to chosen hobbies.
Ability to find and use resources or tools to advance skills in hobbies.
Engaging in recreational activities with others.
Ability to communicate, cooperate, and participate actively in group activities.
Skills in leading group activities and taking initiative.
The ability to maintain personal safety and health, including recognizing dangerous situations and the knowledge of how to access medical care.
Understanding and recognizing potentially dangerous situations.
Ability to react appropriately in emergency situations.
Basic training and understanding of first aid procedures.
Knowledge and skills to manage one's health and access medical care.
Ability to comprehend and use health-related information effectively.
Skills to locate and evaluate health information from digital resources.
Ability to engage and participate in community and social settings, including following social norms and contributing to social groups.
Participation in community activities and events.
Engaging in volunteer activities within the community.
Skills related to planning and coordinating community events.
Understanding and adhering to social conventions and norms.
Knowledge of appropriate behaviors and practices in various social situations.
Understanding and adapting to social norms in different cultural contexts.
Skills and judgment to manage money, budget, and plan financially for the future.
Ability to create and maintain a personal or household budget.
Monitoring and recording personal or household expenditures.
Ability to analyze and make informed decisions about spending patterns.
Ability to move safely and efficiently within different environments, including using public transportation or driving if applicable.
Ability to utilize public transportation effectively and safely.
Ability to plan and navigate routes using public transport systems.
Skills in managing transfers between different modes of transport.
Skills and knowledge required to drive safely and adhere to traffic laws.
Understanding and adhering to traffic rules and safety practices.
Ability to anticipate and react to potential hazards on the road.
Motivation driven by internal rewards, where activities are performed for personal satisfaction or interest.
Motivation driven by genuine interest and enjoyment in the task itself.
Motivation driven by the desire to explore and learn new things out of curiosity.
Motivation to engage in activities that involve discovering new experiences or information.
Seeking hands-on activities to gain firsthand experience and understanding.
Gaining knowledge or experience through observation or listening rather than direct interaction.
Motivation to inquire and seek answers or deeper understanding.
Asking questions to gain a clearer understanding of a subject or situation.
Inquiring in ways that broaden the scope of understanding beyond immediate facts.
Motivation arising from the enjoyment and fun experienced during the activity.
Engaging in activities with a sense of play and enjoyment.
Expressing creativity and imagination through playful activities.
Engaging in fun and interactive activities with others.
Feeling of contentment and fulfillment gained from engaging in tasks.
Deriving pleasure from finishing tasks or projects.
Enjoyment derived during the process of engaging in tasks, regardless of the outcome.
Motivation that arises from finding pleasure in overcoming challenges.
Motivation to develop competence and master new skills.
Motivation to enhance and acquire new competencies or skills.
Focusing on improving and polishing existing skills.
Acquiring completely new skills to broaden expertise and capabilities.
Commitment to ongoing self-improvement and education.
Engaging in structured educational programs or courses.
Learning that occurs outside formal educational settings, such as through reading or experiences.
Motivation to bounce back and stay determined after encountering difficulties.
Adjusting strategies and approaches in response to challenges.
The ability to adapt thoughts and solutions when facing new challenges.
Changing strategies or approaches when current ones are ineffective.
Continuing efforts despite experiencing setbacks or failures.
Maintaining emotional strength in the face of repeated failure.
Using problem-solving and analytical abilities to persist through difficulties.
Motivation driven by external rewards, such as praise, money, or recognition, rather than personal satisfaction.
Motivation that is heavily dependent on tangible rewards like money or gifts.
Motivation due to financial rewards or incentives.
Increased motivation from additional monetary compensation beyond regular salary.
Motivation through periodic financial distributions for meeting set tasks or responsibilities.
Motivation driven by the receipt of tangible, non-monetary rewards.
Motivation to gain physical, non-monetary rewards for achievement or effort.
Incentives in the form of special rights or advantages given as a reward.
Motivation driven by the desire for social acknowledgment and status.
Motivation driven by the desire to achieve a high status or position of influence.
Aspiration to hold positions that involve leading groups or projects.
Motivation to exert control or sway over others and situations.
Motivation fueled by the need for social acceptance and approval from others.
Desire to be accepted and validated by one's social group.
Seeking confirmation and recognition from others regarding one's actions and worth.
The process of identifying specific objectives to achieve and planning strategies to accomplish them.
Setting objectives that are achievable in a short time period.
Establishing goals that are intended to be achieved within a day.
Creating and managing lists of tasks to accomplish daily objectives.
Allocating specific time periods to complete tasks within a day efficiently.
Setting goals that span a week's timeline for completion.
Organizing and setting short-term plans for project completion over a week.
Monitoring and recording progress towards weekly objectives.
Planning and aiming for goals that take a longer time to accomplish.
Long-term plans and aspirations related to professional development.
Strategies to achieve upward movement in one's professional field.
Setting goals to learn new skills that may take longer to develop.
Broad life-oriented goals that encapsulate personal values and aspirations.
Long-term commitment to enhancing personal qualities and capabilities.
Setting goals to contribute positively to society over the long term.
The ability to maintain effort and interest over time in pursuit of long-term goals.
Sustained effort towards goals despite challenges or obstacles.
The practice of training oneself to adhere to rules or standards of behavior despite difficulties.
Maintaining consistency in behaviors or tasks to support long-term objectives.
Exerting control over one's actions and impulses towards discipline.
Commitment to a task or purpose even in the face of adversity.
Concentration on a task or goal without being distracted by external factors.
Deep engagement and dedication to achieving set goals.
Focusing on finer details and accuracy while persisting towards a goal.
Motivation to achieve precision and correctness in task execution.
Diligent verification for errors in work to uphold quality and standards.
Paying careful attention to the intricacies and finer aspects of a task.
The careful and comprehensive effort to ensure completeness and accuracy.
Creating detailed plans that consider all aspects of a task or goal.
Executing tasks carefully to ensure they are completed accurately and thoroughly.
The ability to regulate behavior, emotions, and thoughts in the pursuit of long-term goals.
Controlling impulsive actions to stay on track towards goals.
The ability to resist short-term temptations in order to meet long-term goals.
Avoiding momentary pleasures or distractions that may hinder long-term goals.
Balancing the choice between initial impulses and consequent long-term benefits.
The capability to resist the temptation for an immediate reward in preference for a later reward.
Focusing on future benefits to resist present temptations for greater rewards.
Postponing gratification to achieve more favorable results in the long-term.
Managing emotions to remain focused and motivated on the path to goal achievement.
The ability to maintain stability and continue working towards goals under stress.
Techniques used to manage stress effectively while pursuing goals.
Capacity to recover from stress and remain motivated.
The skill to alter one's emotional state to align with task requirements.
Changing perception to a more optimistic view to align emotions with goals.
Utilizing strategies to control one's emotional responses in goal pursuit.
Reflects a person's overall subjective emotional evaluation of their own worth.
Overall value one places on oneself as a person.
Self-worth derived from one's emotional experiences and stability.
Self-worth derived from one's ability to recover from emotional setbacks.
Self-worth derived from one's ability to express emotions effectively.
Self-worth derived from one's physical appearance and abilities.
Self-worth derived from one's level of physical fitness and strength.
Self-worth derived from one's satisfaction with personal appearance.
